briefing.opening: Good morning. I will now begin the climate briefing for February 20, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸŒ±ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Domestic Carbon Neutral Transition and Renewable Energy Expansion
sections.content: Today, various efforts to address climate change have been reported domestically. February tree planting activities are intensifying [1, 3, 13], and amidst the emphasis on the role of seed banks for food security in the climate crisis [4], practical adaptation efforts are continuing in local communities, such as Jangsu County supporting apple farmers with climate change response facilities [8]. Furthermore, policy and technological advancements for transitioning to a carbon-neutral society are actively being pursued. These range from policies encouraging citizen participation, such as Cheongsong County's 'Drive Diet' and recruitment for the vehicle carbon neutrality point system [10, 12, 15], to the government's declaration of the first year of the next-generation distributed power grid [11], Yangpyeong County's selection for the new and renewable energy convergence support project [17], Boseong County's promotion of an energy-independent city [18], and the growing attention to offshore hybrid power generation technology [19]. These efforts are proceeding under specific goals, such as Jinju City's 2026 carbon-neutral transformation plan [14], and are being expanded through regional cooperation by Korea Aerospace University [16] and international cooperation by KEPCO KDN [23].

sections.title: âš ï¸ğŸ”´ Increased Socioeconomic Risks Domestically and Internationally Due to Climate Change
sections.content: The impacts of climate change are now emerging as concrete risks throughout our society. In the domestic insurance industry, a 'reluctance to underwrite' certain products created by climate change is occurring, highlighting the importance of public-private joint response [2, 6]. Overseas, avalanche risks in the Sierra Nevada and Lake Tahoe regions are being reshaped or becoming more complex due to climate change [24, 38], and there are reports that Valencia's deadly floods have also intensified due to climate change [40]. The global increase in 'fire weather synchronicity,' putting pressure on international firefighting resources [45], and the EU's announcement of a '3-degree' warning [51] demonstrate the widespread impacts of climate disasters. This clearly shows that no one can escape the effects of climate change [25], just as Maryland is facing the reality of climate change, from energy issues to floods [33].

sections.title: ğŸ”´ğŸŒ International Climate Policy Reversals and Political Controversies
sections.content: Internationally, policy setbacks and political controversies regarding climate change response continue unabated. There have been reports that claims related to former President Trump's attempts to abolish greenhouse gas standards are based on misinformation [26, 39], and concerns have also been raised that his administration sought to remove 'endangerment findings' related to greenhouse gases and threatened climate science in polar regions [46, 48, 52]. These moves, coupled with warnings that they could lead to unbearable consequences for Texas [37], and analyses suggesting that climate change is stimulating former President Trump's interest in the Panama Canal [29], illustrate the complex relationship between politics and climate change. The incident where climate change-related signs were removed from Acadia National Park, triggering a lawsuit [34], is a clear example of the social conflict surrounding climate change awareness and information dissemination.

sections.title: ğŸŒğŸ“° Global Climate Adaptation Efforts and Complex Realities
sections.content: Globally, adaptation efforts to climate change are ongoing, alongside various societal discussions. Ski resorts are responding to the impacts of climate change by utilizing snow-making stickers [27], and everyday efforts to combat climate change in gardens, such as 'birdscaping,' have also been introduced [36]. Discussions on climate change adaptation are taking place across Canada [47], and understanding through scientific observation is deepening, with Lake Superior's ice conditions providing important information about climate change [30]. However, news that residential buildings in New York City are struggling to meet decarbonization targets [42] and discussions on the problems of global-scale solar geoengineering interventions [50] demonstrate the complexity of resolving the climate crisis. Furthermore, the Australian government's decision to permit a specific mining company to clear forests despite environmental destruction controversies [49], and the prospect that flood-prone areas in the UK, once only habitable in summer, could revert to that state due to climate change [44], suggest economic dilemmas and long-term climate change impacts.

briefing.closing: Today's briefing clearly illustrates the urgency of climate change response, global efforts, and the political and socioeconomic challenges we simultaneously face. Wisdom and action for a sustainable future are more crucial than ever. This concludes today's climate briefing.
